course.name: Basic Web Course 1 - Learning the basics
course.courseDescription: This course will cover the basics of HTML, CSS, Javascript, XML and AJAX requests.

unit.title: HTML & CSS Basics
unit.unitDescription:
Html is the basis for all websites. It is capable of marking up information for most modern browsers and allows web developers to customize and display web items easily. CSS is also useful for presenting your web page in a specific format that is visually appealing. A great benefit is that once a CSS file is created, you can apply it to many other html pages easily. Within this tutorial you will become familiar with the following topics:
  • Create basic html template
  • How to display text
  • How to create hyperlinks
  • How to display buttons
  • How to create Headers and Footers
  • How to create style objects
  • How to create mouse events

To wrap up unit 1, we will introduce you to some mouse events to enhance the website design experience! You can add some functionality with some buttons or HTML elements to do something when your mouse does something. The following are some of the most common events that you may want to handle
  • onMouseEnter
  • onMouseOut
  • onMouseDown
  • onMouseUp

lessonContent.title: onMouseEnter/onMouseOver
lessonContent.content: Use this Mouse Event when you want to make changes to your design on an html element when the mouse has entered the element area (at least once) or is hovering over the area.

lessonContent.title: onMouseDown/onMouseUp
lessonContent.content: Use these events when you want to enable some functionality when a user is holding down the mouse, and/or letting go of the mouse (mouse up)

unit.title: Javascript Basics
unit.unitDescription:
Javascript enables a web developer to add countless customizable functional behaviours to a site. This can involve implement algorithms to run for a tool, to manipulating elements based on specific button presses, to utilizing AJAX (Learned in Unit 3Unit 3) to create a smooth and responsive web interface. The following topics will be covered within this unit:
  • Creating a javascript file
  • How to create variables and arrays
  • How to create functions
  • Variable types
  • Accessing the DOM (Document Object Model)
  • Handling events

lessonContent.content: Creating a javascript file is as easy as creating a file with any name, then add '.js' at the end. (e.g. someFileName.js). No need to add anything within the file just yet...

Variables and Arrays are essential when creating utilizing Javascript with your web page. They can help store, track, and manipulate pieces of data that you can use. In the following code example you can create a variable called 'test' that can hold a string, and also create a variable called 'count' to keep count of something. To create these variables, you need to use either of the following keywords before the variable name:
  • let
    • This keyword is similar to var where it instantiates a variable, however it will only be available to the current scope of code it is in, and not be declared global
  • var
    • This keyword will create a global variable that can be used throughout an entire javascript file
  • const
    • This keyword will create a variable, but you will not be able to change anywhere else in the code. This is helpful to make sure you want to use data that shouldn't ever need to change.

To create an array is also pretty simple in javascript. Simply create a variable, but after the equals sign, use square brackets to create an 'array' and enter data through a 'comma seperated list'.
Note: all of the entries within an array variable must all be of the same type!

All variables within javascript are built upon types. These types will help with organizing the data that you may want to use/manipulate. The following are some of the most common types used:
  • string
    • This type is used to define words, characters and sets of characters (e.g. "this word is a string")
  • number
    • This type is used to define number arithmatic (e.g. 0, 12, 12.3)
  • object
    • This type is used to define any object within javascript. It is almost like a wild card.
  • boolean
    • This type is used to describe logical results (e.g. True, False)
These variable types are normally automatically determined by the javascript compiler, so you don't have to also specify what type a variable should be. This does, however, create uncertainty when testing with variables and a developer may be unsure as to why a variable changed type halfway through a function.

Functions can help take you website to the next level! Functions created in a javascript file can be linked with an html page, and be used with many events within the web page. For example, if you created a button within the web page, clicking it can activate a function that will do whatever it was programmed.

Javascript will give you the ability to make these changes anywhere within the active DOM (i.e. the active web page). unit.title: XML and AJAX
unit.unitDescription:
XML and AJAX are powerful when used correctly. XML is a markup language to help organize large amounts of data in an easy to read interface that can be referenced for any application (e.g. store data). AJAX is a web development method to asynchronously manipulate elements within an HTML page to make the response look 'fast' and 'intuitive'. You will learn the following topics:
  • Create and XML Document
  • How to create XML tags
  • How to view XML
  • How to add XML elements
  • How does XSD (XML Shema) work
  • How does XSL (XML Styling) work
  • How to create an AJAX method
  • How to create JSON objects

lessonContent.content: To create an xml document, it is as easy as creating an empty file with the following name convention (e.g. fileName.xml). Once that is complete, we can begin adding the main content of the xml file.

XML is a type of formatting language to store data to be used in other web pages. It is an alternative to the JSON format. In order to organise all of the data into a readable format, XML tags are utilized to store the information. Tags will look very similar to that of HTML tags, however, the difference is that for XML tags, they can be named almost anything. It is up to you, the developer, to decide how you want to set up these tags. A tag hierarchy may need to be created to store information (e.g. Person ---contains---> ((Name --contains--> First Name, Last Name), Age, Height)). See the following image as an example.
Note: a good rule of thumb is to not make your tag names too long, and to always start the tag name with a lowercase letter. Leave tags that start with an uppercase letter to the "highest level"
You can either view an XML file within a code editor, or even within an internet browser! Simply open them up using your computers method of choice.

XML elements are the contents within each of the tags. They can be another XML tag or just plain text. They're also what specifies the exact heirarchy of the data that it represents. If we look back at a previous image...

...this image displays data for a personal contact. Within the tag "ResumeGeneralContactInfo" there are additional tags that are children of that XML element, such as "fullname, mailing_address, phone_number, email_address". This is what XML data is useful for, if we use the correct element structure, we can easily read what data we need within a website.

XSD (XML Schema Definition) is used to help validate that a certain XML file (within the same file path) is in the correct format, specified within the .xsd file. This can help ensure that the XML data potentially being received within a website has the correct format to correctly read the data, otherwise it is rejected. See the following image as an example:

Within this file, there are 'xml' tags containing names that start with xs:simpletype, and so on. You will order these tags based on how you want the information to be formatted within the original XML file. These are the most common types that you should be aware of:
  • simpleType
    • This type is to format a single xml tag with a specific name
  • complexType
    • This type is to format a complex xml tag that may contain additional children xml tags within, and also specify any additional attributes within those xml tags, as well as single xml elements.
  • pattern
    • This element is used within a simpletype to match xml content with a specific string pattern. This is used in conjuction with a restriction element.
  • restriction
    • This element is used to specify a specific restriction that a piece of xml data must have (e.g. a number must be less than 100, must match a certain string pattern)
  • element
    • This element (also called element) can be used to quickly specify a single xml element with a type (e.g. string, number)
  • sequence
    • This element is used to specify the amount of identical children that a single xml tag may have. Essentially, if there are supposed to be multiple child entries within a parent XML tag

XSL (XML Style Language) is another that is used to display XML data in a readable fashion within a browser. It will contain an html section that will be the template for what the data can look like. See the following image as a base example:

A JSON object is another alternative of storing information within a file to read within a website. It can potentially be easier to read the information compared to XML files. It uses an object-like structure to display its information, and you can store arrays, strings, other JSON objects. Simply create the JSON object to look like the following example: (NOTE: If you want to use an array, follow the exact format as this image, but for a single object, just copy the same format from one of the entries)

Using an AJAX HTTP method can help make your website look more seemless and very responsive. Essentially, create an AJAX function in javascript will send an asynchronous request to the server to gether information from another url link (local or from the internet). The basis of the AJAX method is as follows:
  • Create a function that will occur once an HTTP request is made. This function can be in charge of gathering data, manipulating HTML objects based on certain criteria, or updating an online service
  • Create an XMLHttpRequest() object and add that function when "onReadyStateChange" event will occur
  • Send the asynchronous request and let the function take over once the call is a success
Note: in order for these AJAX calls to work, the html page must be hosted on a server. This can be done with a local program, or saving the file on a hosted site.
